Related Trust Policies (to be read in conjunction with)
MESPO-19018 Point of care testing policy and procedure
Summary of amendments/ Record documents superseded by:
Newly created; MSE document template and logo. Introduction of point of care testing for COVID-19 using the Abbott ID NOW™

data.text: Contents
Introduction

Point of Care Testing (POCT), or near patient testing (NPT), is a term used to describe  laboratory  testing  performed  usually  by  non-laboratory  staff,  mainly medical and nursing staff outside the main laboratory.

ID NOW COVID-19 is a rapid (13 minutes or less), instrument-based isothermal test for the qualitative detection and diagnosis of SARS-CoV-2 (the virus responsible for the disease COVID-19) from nasal swabs. The ID NOW Instrument has a small footprint and easy to use graphical user interface for convenience within a busy hospital or near patient testing environments. The ID NOW COVID-19 kit contains all components required to carry out an assay for SARS-CoV-2 on the ID NOW Instrument.

This procedure covers the point of care testing for SARS-CoV-2 using the Abbott ID NOW™. This procedure describes when and how to correctly use the Abbott ID NOW in order to minimise risk to both patient and user. Only individuals trained and deemed competent by approved assessment in the use of the Abbott ID NOW™ are authorised to use this procedure.
Scope
The purpose of this document:
The Abbott ID NOW™ is a point of care molecular in vitro diagnostic test that aids in the rapid detection and diagnosis of SARS-CoV-2.
It can be used in addition to the routine screening for swab for SARS-CoV-2 which is sent to the Microbiology department for testing.

The procedure applies to all staff working on sites where the Trust requires screening for SARS-CoV-2 upon admission to hospital. Testing is performed when ordered by the patient's health care provider.
Definitions
Role and responsibilities within the Trust
Individual responsibilities (i.e. Committees)
4.1.1 POCT group
Ensuring that this policy is adhered to.
Responsibility for the periodic review of this policy.
Ensuring that validation/verification of the Abbott ID NOW™ for SARS-CoV-2 testing is completed and the test is implemented.
Respond to areas that do not adhere to safe practise such as failing to complete QC.
Individual responsibilities (i.e. Chief Executive)

4.2.1 Chief Executive – The Chief Executive has overall responsibility to ensure the safe operation of all POCT within the Trust. These duties are delegated to Clinical and Service Directors in their respective health divisions.
4.2.2 Clinical and Service Directors
Ensure that all staff are trained and competent to use the Abbott ID NOW™ within their division.
Ensure that the training records are shared with Pathology who must hold a central bank of all those trained.
4.2.3 Pathology Department

Responsible for setting overall strategy and policy to support the effective identification and management of risks that are associated with the acquisition, use, maintenance and repair of the Abbott ID NOW™.
Assist with interpretation of results.
Troubleshooting where possible.
Assistance with writing of standard operating procedure (SOP).
Comparability to the laboratory method if available.
Review incidences rates and ensure there is a clear guidance offered when there is an increase.
When the prevalence increases the flow chart the patient flow chart may need to
be reviewed.
4.2.4 POCT Coordinator:
To be the contact point for the Trust for all analytical aspects of the Abbott ID NOW™.
To direct queries as appropriate.
To monitor all appropriate systems to ensure that The Abbott ID NOW™ are running efficiently.
Where appropriate to write SOP's for users and to offer advice to others regarding content.
To assist with any suggested and appropriate laboratory comparison.
To highlight any clinical errors/queries to the POCT clinical lead.
4.2.6 Named individual in charge of a location/Team Leader

The Team Leader is accountable for the safe care and management of any patients tested for SARS-CoV-2 with the Abbott ID NOW™. They are therefore responsible for ensuring that all staff involved in testing fully comply with this document and for implementing a system to provide assurance that this is always the case.
4.2.7 All staff using/operating Abbott ID NOW™
Ensure that they are trained to use the equipment.
Ensure they use the equipment for its intended purpose.
Ensure they comply with this policy.
To report any incidences involving the Abbott ID NOW™ through Datix.
Abbott ID NOW COVID-19
Reagents, equipment and material
The Abbott ID NOW™ instruments should be located in a point of care testing room in clinical areas of the hospital.
Reagents and equipment required for QC and patient testing are as follows:
Abbott ID NOW™ instruments
Abbott ID NOW™ COVID-19 kits
Abbott ID NOW™ COVID-19 positive control
Nerbe Plus dry swab (09-511-5017)
Clinical Waste Bin
70% Alcohol wipes
rd Party SARS-CoV-2 Process Control (Microbiologics)
rd Party Negative Cellularity Control (Microbiologics)
Labels for printer
Storage and handling
Abbott ID NOW™ COVID-19 kits should be stored at  - 30°C. All test components should be at room temperature before use.
Proper sample collection, storage and transport are essential for correct results.
Leave test pieces sealed in their foil pouches until just before use.
Do not tamper with test pieces prior to or after use.
Do not use kit past its expiration date.
Wear clean personal protection equipment and gloves when running each test. Change gloves between the handling of specimens suspected of COVID-19.

If any assay components are dropped, cracked, found to be damaged or opened when received, DO NOT USE and discard. Do not use scissors or sharp objects to open foil pouches as damage to test pieces can occur.
Do not open the Sample Receiver before placing in the instrument. It will prohibit the Elution Buffer from reaching temperature and may impact test performance.
If  the  Sample  Receiver  is  spilled  while  opening,  clean  the  instrument  per instructions provided in the instrument User Manual and cancel test. Repeat test with a new Sample Receiver.

All  test  pieces  must  be  removed  from  the  instrument  according  to  removal instructions displayed on the instrument and disposed of according to country and local requirements. Pieces must not be separated once they are assembled.
All test pieces are single use items. Do not use with multiple specimens.

Once  reacted,  the  Test  Base  contains  large  amounts  of  amplified  target (Amplicon). Do not disassemble the Test Base and Transfer Cartridge. In the case of a positive sample, this could lead to amplicon leakage and potential ID NOW COVID-19 false positive test results.
Internal Quality Control Testing

ID NOW COVID-19 contains an internal control that has been designed to control for sample inhibition and assay reagent function. In positive samples where target amplification is strong, the internal control is ignored and the target amplification serves as the ‘control' to confirm that the clinical sample was not inhibitory and that assay reagent performance was robust. At a very low frequency, clinical samples can contain inhibitors that may generate invalid results.

Procedural  Control  Valid  displayed on  the instrument  screen indicates that  the assay  reagents  maintained  their  functional  integrity  and  the  sample  did  not significantly inhibit assay performance.

Each Abbott ID NOW™ instrument must have st party (kit control) and 3rd party positive and negative controls (Microbiologics) run and pass daily. The kit positive control consists of a swab with lyophilized control material, and is provided in each

kit box. The kit negative control is simply a blank swab. The 3rd party controls are lyophilized  in  pellet  form  and  can  be  stored  between  2-25°C  in  the  original packaging. When required for use, the controls are rehydrated with 1ml of molecular grade water and shaken vigorously until the pellet is completely dissolved. The controls must then be stored at 4°C and used within 5 days.
The control can be used a maximum of 5 times before it should be discarded. For more information see section 6.6.
Specimen Requirements
A nasal sample taken using a Nerbe Plus dry swab is suitable for testing. No other sample type should be tested.
Procedure for performing a test
Taking a sample

To collect a nasal swab sample, carefully insert the swab into the nostril exhibiting the most visible drainage, or the nostril that is most congested if drainage is not visible. Using gentle rotation, push the swab until resistance is met at the level of the turbinates (less than one inch into the nostril). Rotate the swab several times against the nasal wall then slowly remove from the nostril. Using the same swab, repeat sample collection in the other nostril.
Specimen transport and storage

Direct nasal swabs should be tested as soon as possible after collection. If immediate testing is not possible, the nasal swab can be held at room temperature (15-30°C) for up to two hours prior to testing. If a direct nasal swab specimen will be held longer than two hours, it must be refrigerated at 2-8°C and tested within 24 hours from the time of sample collection.
Use freshly collected specimens for optimal test performance. Inadequate specimen collection or improper sample handling/storage/transport may yield erroneous results.
Test procedure
Before testing with ID NOW COVID-19:
Put on a clean pair of gloves.
Allow all samples to reach room temperature.
Allow all test pieces to reach room temperature.

Check that a reagent pellet is visible at the bottom of the reaction tubes prior to inserting the Test Base in the ID NOW Instrument. Do not use the Test Base if a pellet is not visible at the bottom of each reaction tube.
Caution: Do not apply excessive force. Excessive force could damage the instrument.

Caution: Once the Test Base has been placed in the holder, the user will have 10 minutes to confirm the test. If the test is not confirmed within 10 minutes, the instrument will time out and the Test Base must be removed and discarded.
Caution: Do not apply excessive force. Excessive force could damage the instrument.

Caution: Once the Sample Receiver has been placed in the holder, the user will have 10 minutes to start the test. If the test is not started within 10 minutes, the instrument will time out and all test pieces (Test Base and Sample Receiver) must be removed and discarded. The instrument will proceed to the Home screen. Press Run Test and restart the test using a new Test Base and Sample Receiver.

Caution: To ensure that the Sample Receiver remains in the instrument while removing the foil seal, place two fingers along the outer edge of the Sample Receiver to hold it in place. If the Sample Receiver spills after warm up, cancel the test by pressing the Home button. Remove and discard the test pieces (Sample Receiver and Test Base) and clean the instrument. Press Run Test to start a new test using a new Test Base and Sample Receiver.
Caution: The orange indicator should be observed closely. If the orange indicator does not fully rise, the Transfer Cartridge may not collect enough sample.
Caution: If the orange indicator does not fully descend, not enough sample will be dispensed. This may potentially result in invalid or false test results.

Caution: This screen will be displayed for up to  seconds once the Transfer Cartridge is detected. If the instrument does not detect that the lid has been closed by then, it will time out and all test pieces (Sample Receiver, Test Base, and Transfer Cartridge) must be removed and discarded. The instrument will proceed to the Home screen. Collect a new sample from the patient. Press Run Test and restart the test using a new Test Base and Sample Receiver.

Caution: The test is not saved until the completed result is displayed. DO NOT OPEN THE LID until the results are displayed. The test will be cancelled and all test pieces (Sample Receiver, Test Base, and Transfer Cartridge) must be removed and discarded. A test result will not be reported or saved in the instrument memory.
The Test Results screen displays either a Negative or Positive result for a
successfully completed test. If a test error occurs, the display will read ‘Invalid'. Refer to the Result Interpretation Section for Interpretation of Results.
Caution: Do not try to remove the Sample Receiver by any other method as there is a risk of spilling the patient sample.
Caution: DO NOT disassemble the Transfer Cartridge and the Test Base before disposal.
Interpretation of results
Table 1: Result Interpretation (taken from ID NOW COVID-19 Product Insert IN191000 Rev.1 2020/09)

data.url: MSEGL-21010 Abbott ID NOW Covid-19 user handbook 1.0.003.jpeg

data.text: If an Invalid result is received,  one additional test may be run using the same Sample Receiver, following the steps below:

Remove the connected Test Base and Transfer Cartridge from the instrument and connect the Test Base portion to an open, UNUSED Sample Receiver. The connected Test Base and Transfer Cartridge MUST be attached to a Sample Receiver prior to disposal. The Sample Receiver from a new Transfer Cartridge package may be used for this.
Remove the blue Sample Receiver separately and carefully from the instrument. The Sample Receiver should be retained and kept upright to avoid spilling the liquid contents.
From the Home Screen, start a new test. Follow the screen prompts; however, when asked to insert the Sample Receiver, reuse the Sample Receiver and DO NOT re-elute the swab.
Actions following Abbott ID NOW Result
Following the algorithm attached in Appendix 2 in time of low prevalence:

Positive: If patient is symptomatic then treat patient as COVID-19 positive and they can be allocated to a RED bed in the hospital. Send a nose and throat swab in viral transport medium to Microbiology for confirmation PCR; however there is no need to wait for the PCR test result.
Negative: If the patient is asymptomatic, then the patient can be admitted to non COVID-19 ward of the appropriate specialty.

If Abbott ID NOW result is negative and there remains a clinical suspicion of COVID-19, admit them to a side room or COVID suspected socially distanced bay on the assessment unit and send a repeat PCR swab to Microbiology.
Should prevalence of SARS-CoV-2 begin to increase, the algorithm will be reviewed and double swabbing of patients may be required.
Quality Control (QC) Procedure For kit QCs:
For rd party QCs:
rd party QCs must be run as patient samples.
If the QC fails, try to rerun the QC and if it fails again, contact the POCT team. DO NOT RUN ANY PATIENT SAMPLES UNTIL THE QCs HAVE BOTH PASSED.

Troubleshooting Should any issues occur with the Abbott ID NOW instruments, for example repeated failure of QC or instrument breakdown, contact the POCT team. Abbott customer support is available Monday to Friday  –  and can be contacted on EME.Techsupport@abbott.com or +44 (0) 161 483 5884 (Option 3). Should support from Abbott be required out of ours Claire Leelane, Medical Science Liaison Team Leader can be contacted on 07899 966182.
Reporting results
Every test result, positive and negative, should be logged by the department and documented in the patients' notes.
The sticker printed by the Abbott ID NOW instrument should be attached to the notes
Every test result should be recorded on the form as per Appendix
All test results must be reported to Public Health England (PHE) using the online portal on at least a weekly frequency, but ideally daily.
Reporting Results to PHE
All results should be documented in the patients' notes and logged on a list by the nurse co-coordinator in ED.
All results must be submitted to PHE as per legal requirements.
An ED registered username and password can be obtained by emailing: poct.contact@phe.gov.uk.
PHE will provide an Excel template that can be used and submitted to the following web portal:
https://apps.powerapps.com/play/482bd56a-3a99-4899- 862bf24eae6ea876?tenantId=ee4e1499-4a35-4b2e-ad47-5f3cf9de8666
Training requirements

Each “operator” using the Abbott ID NOW™ becomes competent through training provided by the Trust (in association with Abbott) or through a POCT Superuser. Any question regarding training can be forward to the POCT team:
Broomfield Site Via e-mail MSE.POCT-team@nhs.net or telephone 01245 514152 (or x4152)
Southend Site Via e-mail MSE.POCT.SUFT@nhs.net or telephone x 6612
Basildon Site Via e-mail MSE.POCT.BTUH@nhs.net or telephone x8382
Cascade training can be requested through your Superuser or coordinated by the POCT team.

All trained users are responsible for informing the POCT team of any changes or problems with the Abbott ID NOW™ instruments (e.g. broken Abbott ID NOW™ or Abbott ID NOW™ that does not pass the quality assurance test).
Only individuals who have fulfilled the following criteria will be allowed to undertake Abbott ID NOW™ testing:
Role and Responsibility of a SUPERUSER - it is the SUPERUSER responsibility to ensure that new staff or those that have missed the training follow the steps below:
Ensure that the staff are trained per manufacturer specifications
That trained staff are competency assessed
Understand the importance of QC testing
Understand the correct technique to take and run a sample
Understand the limitations of the Abbott ID NOW™
When to escalate an issue to the POCT team

Role and Responsibility of the USER once trained is to ensure they are trained and re-trained on a regular basis to ensure good practise is maintained. It is also the responsibility of trained staff to understand the following:
Understand the importance of QC testing
Understand the correct technique to take and run sample
Understand the limitations of the Abbott ID NOW™
When to escalate an issue to the nurse in charge or POCT team
Monitoring and audit
Outlined below is the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.

table_items.text: Aspect of compliance or effectiveness being monitored
Individual department responsible for the monitoring
Group / Committee / forum which will receive the findings/monitoring report
Committee / individual responsible for ensuring the actions are completed

data.text: The evidence that this Policy has been followed will be:
Periodic  competency,  training,  safety  and  policy  compliance  audits  will  be performed.
Audits will also include review of any risk events that had occurred internally during audited period (i.e. DATIX /complains).
Audit Findings will be fed back to POCT coordinator/lead nurse via e-mail.
Reports are also issued to Clinical Areas to provide positive and negative feedback.
Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Point of Care team, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local  Point of Care policies. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
POCT coordinator will ensure that all key staff are notified via e-mail about the new version of this document.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals. (Refer to appendix 4)
References
1. ID NOW COVID-19 Product Insert IN191000 Rev.1 2020/09
Appendix 1 – Abbott ID NOW competency document
Abbott ID NOWTM Competency Review Form
Objective
This competency assessment covers the analysis of patient swab samples for SARS-CoV-2 testing using the Abbott ID NOWTM in a point of care testing (POCT) setting. It is the user's professional
responsibility to ensure that they are competent to take nasal samples for analysis.
Related documents: MSE Abbott ID NOW Policy and Quick Guides
Form 1: Abbott ID NOW Competency Review

table_items.text: Device Knowledge: Can identify components of the Abbott ID NOW system Can turn the device on and off

Consumables Knows who to contact to obtain consumables: Reagent cartridges kits, swabs and printer labels Correct procedure for storing and working temperature of device/reagents Knows how and when to check the expiry date on the reagent cartridges

Quality Assurance Understands the reasons for performing internal quality controls (QC) and when to perform this procedure Is able to run the kit positive/negative QC Is able to run the 3rd party positive and negative QC Correct storage, preparation & when to replace QC and actions when QC is unsatisfactory

Patient preparation and correct patient sampling method Knows which type of sample is required Handwashing Confirms correct patient ID prior to collecting sample Knows how to prepare a patient for sampling i.e. ask them to blow their nose and then tilt their head back
Knows to check the expiry date on the swab before collecting the sample Label the swab Knows how the long the sample is stable for and how it should be stored before it is run

Using the Abbott ID NOW to test a patient/3rd party QC sample: Is able to login to the device Can successfully request a COVID-19 test on the device Knows all of the patient information that must be inputted Is able to correctly insert the test base (reagent pack 1) into the device Is able to correctly insert the sample receiver (reagent pack 2) into the device Knows how long the sample receiver must be left in the device before starting the test Is able to remove the lid on the sample receiver Is able to insert the swab into the sample receiver liquid and adequately mix to release the virus into the sample receiver Is able to use the transfer cartridge (reagent pack 2) to transfer the sample to the test base successful Knows when a sample is running and when the test is complete Is able to dispose of the sample/reagents when the test is complete Is able to clean the machine after every sample

Reading and recording of results: Is able to print the results Is able to retrieve the results Understands what a positive, negative, and invalid result means Knows what action to take when there is an invalid result Able to report the number of positive and negative results to NHS England daily
Maintenance: Cleaning and decontamination of Abbott ID NOW and work surface Knows that the analyser will run a ‘self test' after every sample Knows how to replace the printer labels rolls
Health and safety: Awareness of biological hazards & personal protective equipment (gloves, apron) Correct disposal of used gloves, swabs and kits
Troubleshooting Knows who to contact regarding problems

Super Users/Cascade Trainers Only Understands role of Super Users/Cascade Trainers Aware of how to obtain and process appropriate training/ competency documentation Is able to export the data from the analyser

data.text: When to suspect COVID-19:  COVID-19 is NOT suspected/
Asymptomatic
A) Clinical or radiological evidence of pneumonia (fever, cough, breathlessness, with clinical signs OR radiographic changes)
B) Flu-like symptoms: Pyrexia (>38ºC) or history of fever AND flu-like illness [cough, sore throat, rhinorrhoea (runny nose), limb/joint pain, headache]
C) Loss of, or change in, normal sense of taste or smell (anosmia) in isolation or in combination with any other symptoms)  Has patient been known to have COVID-19 in previous 90 days?

table_items.text: ☒ A change in a service to patients
☐ A change to an existing document
☒ A change to the way staff work
What are you proposing to change?
Introduction of point of care testing for COVID-19 using the Abbott ID NOW™
Why are you making this change? (What will the change achieve?)
Rapid screening for COVID-19 will allow for better patient management, better patient flow throughout the hospital, and decreases the risk of transmission of SARS-CoV-2 to staff and other patients.
Who benefits from this change and how?
Patients admitted to the trust, and staff members at risk of SARS-CoV-2 infection.
Is anyone likely to suffer any negative impact as a result of this change? If no, please record reasons here and sign and date this assessment. If yes, please complete a full EIA.
No – rapid screening for SARS-CoV-2 will benefit both patients and staff members.
a) Will you be undertaking any consultation as part of this change?
